item.title: Panama Court Strikes Down Hong Kong Firm’s Canal Contract
item.description: President Trump has said he wants American control of the canal, putting the longtime ports operator, CK Hutchison, in the cross-hairs of the U.S.-China trade conflict.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has frequently said he wants the United States to retake control of the Panama Canal.

item.title: Trump Expected to Announce Kevin Warsh as Fed Chair
item.description: President Trump is set to announce his choice to replace Jerome H. Powell as chair of the Federal Reserve, saying it is someone “known to everybody in the financial world.”
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Ann Saphir/Reuters
item.media:description: President Trump is planning to announce Kevin M. Warsh, a former Federal Reserve governor, as his choice to replace Jerome H. Powell.

item.title: Washington Post Plans Cuts to Reshape Newsroom
item.description: The changes are expected to include significant layoffs in areas like sports and international coverage.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple, Katie Robertson and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Washington Post’s newsroom in 2017.

item.title: California Jury Convicts Ex-Google Engineer of Stealing AI Secrets
item.description: A federal jury found that Linwei Ding stole thousands of confidential files to help him start a company in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Kelsey McClellan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The case is one of several that have surfaced in recent years against Chinese nationals in the United States as the fight for technological dominance ramps up.

item.title: Venezuelan Lawmakers Approve Sweeping Overhaul of Oil Sector
item.description: Bowing to Trump administration pressure, the new legislation improves conditions for foreign oil companies and opens the way to slash the taxes they pay.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue of a hand holding a drilling rig near Venezuela’s state oil company last year.

item.title: Murdoch and News Corp Take on the West Coast with The California Post
item.description: The expansion of the Murdoch tabloid from its New York roots to the West Coast is the latest sign of the outlet’s national ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Photo-illustration by The New York Times; Photos: Getty Images

item.title: Founder of First Brands, Whose Bankruptcy Spooked Wall St., Is Indicted on Fraud Charges
item.description: Patrick James, who was earlier ousted from the beleaguered auto-parts maker, is accused by federal prosecutors of faking invoices and lying about hidden debt for years.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland

item.title: John L. Allen Jr., Journalist With Inside Access to the Vatican, Dies at 61
item.description: He seemed to know everyone at the Holy See, and it showed in his reporting for the National Catholic Reporter and his website, Crux, though some said he grew too close to his sources.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Karen Warren/Houston Chronicle, via Getty Images
item.media:description: John L. Allen Jr. in 2007. “From the end of the 20th century until his death, Allen was essential reading for anyone who cared about the inner workings of the Vatican,” a colleague said.

item.title: Costco Is Sued Over Preservatives in Its $5 Rotisserie Chickens
item.description: A proposed class-action lawsuit claims Costco was misleading customers and engaging in false advertising when it described the chicken as having no preservatives.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two plaintiffs in a lawsuit against Costco said they would not have bought rotisserie chickens if they knew they contained food additives.

item.title: Budget Hotels Become an Immigration Battleground for ICE Protests
item.description: “No sleep” protests have used noise and other tactics to target ICE agents at hotels, leaving the owners, often immigrants themselves, caught in the middle.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung and Claire Fahy
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators took over the lobby of a Hilton Garden Inn in TriBeCa on Tuesday to show solidarity with anti-ICE protests in Minneapolis.

item.title: New Food Stamp Rules Are Confusing Grocery Stores and Consumers
item.description: A dizzying array of rules govern what can be bought with SNAP dollars, confusing grocery stores and consumers.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell and Linda Qiu
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Trade Deficit Widens Despite Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: The monthly trade deficit and imports rebounded in November after shrinking significantly in prior months, new data show.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: The A.I. Boom’s Uncertain Payoff
item.description: Companies like Microsoft and Meta are still spending big on artificial intelligence. But investors remain antsy about seeing results.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investors liked what they heard from Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s C.E.O., about the company’s latest results, including its plans for artificial intelligence.

item.title: Russia’s Lukoil in Talks to Sell Some Assets to U.S. Investment Firm
item.description: The deal with Carlyle comes after the United States and the European Union imposed sanctions on Lukoil, putting a dent in the Kremlin’s oil revenue.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva, Stanley Reed and Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Nikolay Doychinov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Lukoil refinery near Burgas, Bulgaria. The U.S. Treasury Department placed sanctions on the company in October.

item.title: Newark Museum of Art Names a New Leader
item.description: Lisa Funderburke will be chief executive and director of the state’s largest art museum.
item.dc:creator: Hilarie M. Sheets

item.title: Trump’s Trade Policies Sort Manufacturers Into Winners and Losers
item.description: Tariffs have protected some companies, but more often they’ve hit the parts and materials many factories need to make finished goods.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Sylvia Jarrus for The New York Times

item.title: Why Some Cold States Are Making It Cheaper to Run a Heat Pump
item.description: New discounts can make heat pumps go from a bad investment to a good idea.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Paris
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: A Rug Maker Withstood One Year of Trump’s Tariffs. New Challenges Loom.
item.description: Loloi stockpiled rugs from India, Turkey and other countries in advance, but inventory is running low.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: “If the tariffs are 50 percent, no one is passing along 50 percent,” said Amir Loloi, the founder of Loloi, a rug company in Dallas.

item.title: At World’s Busiest Port, China’s Unbalanced Economy Comes Into View
item.description: The shipping traffic and factories never stop in China’s port city of Ningbo, but the local housing market has crashed and nearby restaurants sit empty.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: In Beijing, Starmer and Xi Seek a Way Around a Volatile U.S.
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain is seeking to promote economic ties for growth, offering China’s leader, Xi Jinping, a way to court one of America’s allies.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:credit: Carl Court/Getty Images
item.media:description: Chinese and British delegations participating in a meeting between President Xi Jinping and Prime Minister Keir Starmer in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: Microsoft Continues to Spend Big on A.I. While Profit Jumps 60%
item.description: The company said on Wednesday that revenue in the most recent quarter was $81.3 billion, but its share price dropped more than 7 percent in after-hours trading.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Microsoft continues to spend billions on building out its data center capacity as the demand for A.I. computing power outweighs its available supply.

item.title: What to know about the Fed decision.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Tesla Profit Slumps, but Investors May Not Care
item.description: The automaker also said it would invest $2 billion in xAI, the artificial intelligence company controlled by its C.E.O., Elon Musk, and stop making the two oldest models in its lineup.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Falling car sales have taken a toll on Tesla’s net profit. The company announced Wednesday that it would stop producing its S and X model cars within months.

item.title: Takeaways from the Fed meeting
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman

item.title: Amazon’s $35 Million ‘Melania’ Promotion Has Critics Questioning Its Motives
item.description: The tech giant is spending $35 million to promote its film about the first lady, far more than is typical for documentaries.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon/Reuters
item.media:description: Amazon paid Melania Trump’s production company $40 million for the rights to the documentary. That amount is about $26 million more than the offer from the next closest bidder, Disney.

item.title: The Fed Is Waiting and Watching an Uncertain Economy
item.description: Inflation is elevated but steady and the job market is holding up, leading economists to predict that the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates at current levels.
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith

item.title: Silver Prices Are Surging Even Faster Than Gold
item.description: Silver has risen roughly 60 percent this month alone. What is going on?
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone

item.title: 5 New Stylish Hotels for City Lovers
item.description: New accommodations around the world allow you to soak up urban culture and immerse yourself in hotel creature comforts.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Rosenbloom

item.title: Starbucks Says Turnaround ‘Ahead of Schedule’ as Sales Rebound
item.description: The coffee chain’s stock jumped after a better-than-expected earnings report.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Starbucks coffee shop in Manhattan.

item.title: Five Questions for Jerome Powell, the Fed Chair
item.description: Succession drama, legal intrigue and political independence: These are top issues that DealBook would ask of the Federal Reserve chairman.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Peter Eavis and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jay Powell, the Fed chair, is expected to face tough questions at today’s news conference.

item.title: Clay, an A.I. Sales Start-Up, Lets Employees Cash Out. Again.
item.description: The company is part of a newer generation of software upstarts holding multiple tender offers where workers can sell stock before going public.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Ava Pellor, via Clay
item.media:description: The founders of Clay, a digital marketing start-up, say that letting start-up employees sell shares more regularly helps build up good will.

item.title: Trump’s Political Drama With Powell Overshadows Fed Rate Decision
item.description: The Trump administration has unleashed a barrage of attacks on the Federal Reserve, including a criminal investigation into its chair, Jerome H. Powell.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, has spend much of the past month under siege from President Trump.

item.title: Fed Holds Rates Steady as It Points to an Improving Economy
item.description: The Federal Reserve chose to pause rate cuts, even as it faces relentless attacks from President Trump for not cutting borrowing costs fast enough.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images
item.media:description: “The economy has once again surprised us with its strength, not for the first time,” Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said at a news conference on Wednesday.

item.title: Sundance Film Festival Says Goodbye to Park City, Utah
item.description: “It’s hard not to feel a disturbance in the force,” said Ethan Hawke, whose acting career took off after his early movies appeared at the Utah festival in the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling and Maggie Shannon
item.media:description: “What I will miss most is my youth,” the actor Ethan Hawke said about the Sundance Film Festival’s leaving Park City. “The streets are full of memories.”

item.title: A Municipal Debt Boom Is Driving Public Projects and Tax Breaks for Investors
item.description: Municipal debt issuance surpassed $500 billion last year, a record that’s found a deep pool of buyers.
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith
item.media:credit: Reginald Mathalone/NurPhoto, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Houston is funding billion-dollar renovations to the George Bush Intercontinental Airport by issuing bonds.

item.title: Southwest Begins Assigning Seats, Ending 50 Years of the Boarding Scrum
item.description: The airline said assigned seating, rolled out on Tuesday, aligned with passengers’ preferences, but some customers said the scramble was part of the charm.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Jacob Langston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Southwest Airlines commemorated the end of its longstanding open-seating policy with a celebration on Tuesday morning at Orlando International Airport.

item.title: Bari Weiss Urges CBS News to Think Like a ‘Start-Up’
item.description: “We are not producing a product enough people want,” Ms. Weiss told employees at her first all-staff meeting at the network.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Leigh Vogel/Getty Images
item.media:description: Bari Weiss was appointed editor in chief of CBS News last year.

item.title: UPS Will Cut Up to 30,000 Jobs in 2026
item.description: The delivery company said it was planning the cuts this year because it expected to deliver fewer packages for Amazon, a large but unprofitable customer.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: The announcement that UPS was continuing to thin its work force could add to Americans’ concerns about the job market.

item.title: Microsoft Pledged to Save Water. In the A.I. Era, It Expects Water Use to Soar.
item.description: Driven by the artificial intelligence frenzy, Microsoft is internally projecting that water use at its data centers will more than double by 2030 from 2020, including in places that face shortages.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Karen Weise

item.title: Meta Campaigns to Change Opinions on Data Centers
item.description: The tech giant has spent more than $6 million on TV ads in state capitals and Washington, with the message that data centers create jobs.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan

item.title: She’s the Face of Trump’s Aviation Safety Board, and She’s a Democrat
item.description: Jennifer Homendy, the outspoken chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board, is reclaiming the spotlight at a meeting on Tuesday about the Washington, D.C., crash that killed 67.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jennifer Homendy, the chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board, reconvening a hearing in July on the midair collision above Washington.

item.title: G.M. Shares Rise as Investors Are Encouraged by 2026 Prospects
item.description: The automaker said that it would buy back stock worth up to $6 billion and that it expected profit to rise this year after it pulled back from electric vehicle production.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A General Motors factory in Spring Hill, Tenn. G.M. said on Tuesday it planned to introduce a more advanced version of its Super Cruise driver assistance system in 2028.

item.title: ‘The Outsiders’ Musical Recoups on Broadway
item.description: “The Outsiders” is the first new musical to open since 2022 to become profitable.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: The musical, which received four Tony Awards, opened in April 2024 at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater.

item.title: OpenAI’s Altman and More C.E.O.s Weigh In on Minnesota
item.description: The tech C.E.O. is the latest business leader to speak out about the immigration crackdown and the fatal shooting of two U.S. citizens.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sam Altman, C.E.O. of OpenAI, told employees, “What’s happening with ICE is going too far.”

item.title: Safety Board Blames F.A.A. For Multiple Failures in D.C. Crash
item.description: The National Transportation Safety Board found the probable causes of the midair collision last year included poorly designed flight routes and ignored warnings about risks.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Kate Kelly
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jennifer Homendy, the National Transportation Safety Board chairwoman, speaking after the crash at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport last year. The board plans to publish a full report on the crash.

item.title: As Trump Promotes Economy in Iowa, Many Residents Feel Pain
item.description: Farmers are critical to Iowa’s economy. They have been battered by President Trump’s tariffs and are not experiencing the “golden age” that the president promised.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump visited a restaurant on Tuesday in Urbandale, Iowa. The state has been struggling under his economic policies.

item.title: Fed, Signaling Little Urgency, Prepares to Pause on Rate Cuts
item.description: The Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates steady on Wednesday, despite relentless attacks from President Trump over borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Fed, especially its chair, Jerome H. Powell, have been assailed by President Trump for not lowering interest rates fast enough.

item.title: In Trump’s Shadow, India and the European Union Expand Trade Ties
item.description: After nearly 20 years of negotiations, the two sides struck a far-reaching agreement that officials called “the mother of all trade deals.”
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Manish Swarup/Associated Press
item.media:description: The European Council president, Antonio Costa, and the European Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, came to India to announce a trade agreement nearly 20 years in the making.

item.title: Record Debt in the World’s Richest Nations Threatens Global Growth
item.description: The cost of borrowing is already choking crucial public spending in many developing economies. Now it’s raising broader alarms.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Record-high debt in the United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan risks slowing growth and destabilizing the global economy.

item.title: Trump Administration Takes Another Stake in Rare Earth Sector
item.description: The administration announced a $1.6 billion deal with USA Rare Earth. The firm also does business with Cantor Fitzgerald, which is run by the sons of President Trump’s commerce secretary.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Liam Kennedy for The New York Times
item.media:description: “This investment ensures our supply chains are resilient and no longer reliant on foreign nations,” Howard Lutnick, the secretary of commerce, said of the deal.
